The Related Discourses

760. Three Disagreeable Things

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

At that time, the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “The world has three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable. What are the three? They are old age, illness, and death. These three things are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable. If the world didn’t have these three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable, there wouldn’t be a Tathāgata, an Arhat, or a Perfectly Awakened One who arises in the world. The world wouldn’t know there was a teaching, instruction, or guidance taught by the Tathāgata, either. The Tathāgata, the Arhat, and the Perfectly Awakened One arises in the world because the world has these three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable, and the world does know the teaching, the instruction, and guidance taught by the Tathāgata.”

The monks said to the Buddha, “Isn’t there a path and steps that put an end to these three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable?”

The Buddha told the monks, “There is a path and steps to cultivate and cultivate often that puts an end to these three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable. What is that path and what are those steps to cultivate and cultivate often that put an end to these three things that are disagreeable, unattractive, and immemorable? It’s the noble eightfold path, which is right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra’s introduction is parallel to Pali AN 10.76, but it lacks the remainder of that sutta. Another difference is that the Pali lists birth, old age, and death as the three disagreeable things.
Translator: Charles Patton
